Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The role of integration in driving the morphological diversity of mammalian jaws
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mammals are warm-blooded and so need to eat relatively large quantities of food to maintain their high metabolic rate. Teeth and jaws are the first point of contact with food, and different types of teeth and jaws are specialized for eating different kinds of foods. This relationship has led to a wide range of jaw shapes. For example nectar-eating bats have long and slender jaws for reaching into flowers, whereas spotted hyenas have short and sturdy jaws for crushing bones. Other factors unrelated to feeding can also influence the shape of the jaw, such as the need to make sounds for communication, and digging burrows. Despite these various roles, the shape of mammal jaws is limited by a number of things. Specialised diets (such as bone-crushing or feeding on nectar) often require very specific jaw shapes. Jaw shape is also determined by the genes available to control the way jaws grow. Both of these factors narrow the range of possible jaws shapes that mammals can have. This project investigates how jaw shapes are related to diet and how those shapes have evolved over time. Through this research we will learn how and why jaw shape is very diverse in some groups of mammals and very limited in others. This research will provide STEM training opportunities to undergraduate and high-school students, including women and under-represented minorities, and support science outreach programs in the local community.

The mammalian jaw can be thought of as a functional tool for performing tasks related to feeding, communication, and competition. Developmental evidence suggests that there are two primary regions that can evolve independently, or modules, present in the mammalian jaw: the ramus and corpus. The ramus is the back portion of the jaw and serves as the site of muscle attachments. The corpus is the front portion of the jaw and houses the teeth. As modules become more independent of one another there is greater scope for increasing morphological diversity. However, the extent of co-variation among modules can differ both within and between species. These differences arise due to a variety of genetic and functional constraints. This study uses a combination of morphometric and phylogenetic comparative methods to investigate how modularity has influenced the range of jaw morphologies exhibited by mammals. This project will test two primary hypotheses: 1) the evolution of mammal jaws is characterized by repeated instances of convergence as a result of similarity in diets (i.e., functional demands) among different groups of species, and 2) mammalian jaw diversity is facilitated by reducing the level of co-variation among different modules within the jaw. By addressing these two hypotheses, this study aims to understand how constraints have influenced jaw diversity and how this diversity is distributed within the mammal clade

POR.DRECONTENT:
As warm-blooded animals, mammals need to eat relatively large quantities of food to maintain their high metabolic rate. Teeth and jaws are the first point of contact with food, and different types of teeth and jaws are specialized for eating different types of foods. This relationship has led to a wide range of jaw shapes. Other factors unrelated to feeding can also influence the shape of the jaw, such as the need to make sounds for communication, dig burrows, and sometimes to fight for access to mates (e.g., baboons, elephant seals). Despite these various roles, the shape of mammal jaws is limited by a number of things. Specialised diets (such as bone-crushing or nectar feeding), often require very specific jaw shapes. Jaw shape is also determined by genes that control the way the jaws grow. Both of these factors narrow the range of possible jaws shapes that mammals can have. Broadly speaking, this project investigated how the shapes of mammal jaws are related to diet and climate, and how those shapes have evolved over time.

The mammalian jaw can be thought of as a functional tool for performing tasks related to feeding, communication, and competition. Developmental evidence suggests that there are two primary regions of the jaw that can evolve independently in the mammalian jaw: the ramus and corpus. The ramus is the back portion of the jaw and serves as the site of muscle attachments. The corpus is the front portion of the jaw and houses the teeth. The more independent the two regions are, the greater opportunity for variation in jaw shape. However, the degree of association among these regions of the jaw can differ both within and between species. These differences likely arise due to differences in genes, the environment, and diet. This study used a variety of methods to investigate how the degree of association among regions of the jaw has influenced the range of jaw morphologies exhibited by mammals.

This project tested two primary questions using the jaws of mammals: 1, how does climate and the environment influence the anatomical evolution of jaws, and 2, how do differences in reproduction between marsupial and placental mammals (the gestation times of placentals are longer than marsupials) influence anatomical diversity and does the degree of association among regions of the jaw play a role in patterning their jaw shapes? By addressing these two questions, this study helped to understand how constraints have influenced jaw diversity and how this diversity is distributed over the tree of mammals.

To investigate question 1 we collected jaw measurements and climate data (extracted from species’ range maps) from three groups of mammals: canids (dogs and foxes), felids (cats), and Mustelids (weasels, martens, otters, and badgers).

We found that those members residing in climatically stable regions (e.g., rainforests), exhibited tight associations between the tooth and muscle bearing regions of the jaw, greater anatomical diversity, and faster rates of anatomical evolution relative to members in more climatically variable regions (e.g., temperate and montane regions). This suggests that the climate may have a profound influence on the evolutionary potential of a species. Species may differ in their evolutionary response to climate as a consequence or response, to seasonal variation in food availability. Finally, this study contributes to a growing body of data that can inform how phenotypes may respond to climate change.

To investigate question 2 we collected 3D measurements from the jaws of two major groups of mammals: the placental Order Carnivora (includes dogs, cats, bears) and the marsupial Order Dasyuromorphia (includes numbat, quolls, dunnarts). Marsupials are born at an earlier embryonic stage compared to placental mammals and must suckle immediately. This requires that they have well-developed jaws. As a result, placental and marsupial jaws grow in a very different mechanical environment. We predicted that this difference in mechanical environment influences differences between the two groups in the shape, anatomical diversity, and degree of association between the tooth and muscle bearing regions of the jaw. We found dasyuromorphs exhibit a tight association between the attachment sites for the jaw closing muscles, compared to placental mammals. This pattern of association may result from the overwhelming influence of muscles on the developing jaw. Carnivorans are free from this constraint and muscle-bearing regions on the jaw can evolve independently. Although associations among different regions of the jaw are different, dasyuromorphs and carnivorans display similar levels of anatomical diversity and rates of anatomical evolution. Taken together, this suggests differences in reproduction (short vs. long gestation periods) between marsupial and placental mammals have not affected dasyuriomroph morphological evolution and developing a carnivore-like jaw is a developmentally straightforward task.

 This research also provided training opportunities to undergraduate and high-school students in biological science and statistics. Training programs included women and under-represented minorities, and supported science outreach programs in the local community.
